DOCNAME: CASE OF VIDGEN v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-3-d - Examination of witnesses)
JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and , as far as the ORG is aware , lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( rechtbank ) found the applicant guilty of being a co - perpetrator of the offence of transporting a shipment of tablets containing a psychotropic substance the trade of which is illegal in all countries concerned , namely CARDINAL,CARDINAL-methylenedioxy - N - methylamphetamine ( “ MDMA ” for short , known in its street pill form as “ ecstasy ” or “ XTC ” – the latter designation will be used in this judgment hereafter ) from the GPE to GPE with the intention of ultimately shipping it to GPE . According to the judgment , the ORG was to be hidden in the cylinders and crankcases of motor car engines that would then be shipped to a business , PERSON , in GPE , GPE , which company had been set up by the applicant with a view to importing engine parts from LOC . The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . The proceedings against the applicant were held separately from the proceedings against his co - accused , amongst whom were PERSON and the applicant ’s father , PERSON . The suspects PERSON and PERSON were in fact put on trial in GPE . On DATE they were convicted and given prison sentences by ORG ( Landgericht ) of GPE in GPE for their part in the crimes . They had both made full confessions and given detailed statements to the NORP prosecutors , a fact that was taken into account in sentencing .

CARDINAL . At no point throughout the criminal proceedings against him did the applicant deny that he had been involved in shipping motor car engines to his business in GPE . However , he denied all knowledge of the use of those engines to smuggle ORG and hence any criminal intent directed towards that end . His defence was focused on this point .

CARDINAL . Virtually all the evidence presented before ORG to prove the applicant ’s intent and participation in committing the offence was taken from the statements given by PERSON to the NORP prosecutors and later on to GPE police investigators during the pre - trial stage of the proceedings against the applicant . Particular weight was given to statements PERSON had made with regard to a handwritten note , found in his dwelling , which contained the address of PERSON in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant had repeatedly requested to be allowed to question PERSON since neither he nor his counsel had been present when PERSON had given these statements . At a hearing on DATE ORG noted that both parties had , in the meantime , been to GPE to question the witnesses PERSON and NORP The applicant however specified that the NORP investigating judge had done all the questioning and that he himself had not been able to put any questions to the witnesses . It also appeared that PERSON had refused to answer questions or repeat the statements he had made previously . Furthermore , the prosecutor stated that there had appeared to be a problem with the interpreter assisting the witness PERSON The applicant requested further questioning of the witnesses so that he would actually be able to put his own questions to them .
CARDINAL . At the same hearing ORG decided that the statements given to the NORP prosecutor by PERSON and PERSON would be added to the case file together with the records of their NORP trial .

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE , ORG , finding that the applicant had been able to put questions to PERSON twice ( though without specifying when or where ) , considered that the use in evidence of the statements given by PERSON in GPE did not violate the provisions of LAW . The fact that PERSON had chosen to avail himself of his right not to testify did not alter this situation . ORG also found that PERSON ’s statements were sufficiently supported by other evidence to be allowed to serve as the basis for the applicant ’s conviction .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the judgment of ORG with ORG ( gerechtshof ) . At a hearing on DATE , ORG granted the applicant ’s request for PERSON to be summoned to appear before the court so that they could be heard , given the importance of their statements .

CARDINAL . On DATE and PERSON were both questioned as witnesses at a hearing before ORG . A. stated that he knew the applicant but in general denied ever having talked to him about the XTC . On more specific questions he invoked his right not to testify ( verschoningsrecht ) . A. also declared that everything PERSON had stated was a lie .

CARDINAL . M. acknowledged that he had been questioned by GPE police investigators and admitted that he had been convicted of perjury DATE . He refused however to answer any substantive questions , invoking his right not to testify in connection with pending proceedings for his extradition to the GPE to stand trial on a charge of participation in a criminal organisation .

CARDINAL . In his closing argument the applicant ’s counsel submitted that none of the evidence presented disclosed the applicant ’s intention to commit or participate in the commission of the criminal offence , save only the statement made by PERSON The applicant ’s counsel argued , with reference to the ORG ’s case - law ( including PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL ) , that ORG had based its judgment solely or to a decisive extent on statements made by a witness whom the applicant had not been able to question , thus violating his right to a fair trial under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It considered that the mere fact of PERSON ’s refusal at the hearing to answer any substantive questions did not constitute a violation of the applicant ’s right to have witnesses against him examined . The court noted that PERSON had initially made a confession to the GPE police investigators and had given a full account of events , including about the involvement and extent of participation of his fellow perpetrators . In the course of interviews held at a later stage and at the hearing before ORG on DATE , PERSON had invoked his right not to testify . The court noted , however , that PERSON had not invoked this right in respect of all questions put to him . Thus , he had in any event confirmed that he had indeed said what had been noted down by the GPE police investigators . The question nevertheless arose whether in these circumstances PERSON ’s confessions could be used as evidence in the criminal proceedings against the applicant . For that to be the case , it was required that these statements be largely corroborated by other items of evidence relating to elements which were disputed by the applicant and in respect of which he had wanted to put questions to the witness M.
CARDINAL . ORG reasoning included the following :

“ The defence has argued – in substance – that PERSON ’s initial statements to the police can not be admitted as evidence because he subsequently withdrew them and because the defence has had insufficient opportunity to question PERSON as a witness because DATE in connection with criminal proceedings pending against him in the GPE ... he had , at the hearing of DATE , repeatedly invoked the right not to testify .

The court finds as follows as regards the reliability of the witness and fellow suspect PERSON and the right of the defence to question him . Initially , PERSON made a confession and gave a complete description of the facts , also relating to the involvement and participation of his fellow suspects . Later , questioned under letters rogatory and at the hearing of this court on DATE , PERSON invoked his right not to testify . PERSON ’s refusal to testify at the hearing does not , in itself , violate the right of the defence to question him . In any case , PERSON has not invoked his right not to testify in response to all the questions put and he has at least confirmed that he has made to the GPE investigators the statement which they set down on paper . The question remains , however , to what extent in these circumstances the earlier confessions made by PERSON can and may be admitted as evidence in the present criminal case . For that , it will be required that these statements be largely corroborated ( in belangrijke mate worden bevestigd ) by other evidence on those aspects which [ the applicant ] contests and about which he would have wished to question the witness .

The court notes that the suspects PERSON and PERSON were sentenced to imprisonment for DATE and DATE , respectively , for the illegal import and the illegal trade in psychotropic substances by the Landgericht of GPE . In arriving at a conviction , the NORP court has , in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ... , held as follows concerning A. :

‘ ... In this connection ... it has to be noted in the suspect ’s favour that he made a complete confession at the trial , which made it easier especially for the suspect PERSON to repeat at the hearing the confession which he had already made already following his arrest , which moreover was thus confirmed . This chamber holds in favour of the suspect A. that he has made his confession in spite of a concrete threat to his person and his family by the people in the background of this drugs deal . A. ’s confession additionally has the effect of LAW of the [ NORP ] GPE , ... The statement of the suspect PERSON , which has already led to considerable success in clearing up this case and also in the GPE investigation , is strengthened ( bekrachtigd ) by the additional and confirming statement of the suspect A. ... ’
In sentencing PERSON , the NORP court has held as follows :

‘ Because , as in the case of the suspect A. , the primary standard sentence of DATE imprisonment ... must be mitigated ... pursuant to section CARDINAL of the [ NORP ] Narcotics Act . It must , however , be counted considerably in favour of the suspect PERSON that he has made a complete confession at an early stage of the investigation , although his family and he himself have received specific threats . This confession is also inspired by contrition and insight ... ”

At this court ’s hearing of DATE M. first stated that there had been a deal in his case and afterwards that there had never been any mention of a deal . On this ground , the court finds – contrary to what the defence has argued DATE that it is not established that there was a deal agreed between PERSON as suspect and the NORP prosecution service to make statements incriminating ( also ) his fellow suspects in exchange for a reduction of sentence . Conversely , the NORP court gave reasons for applying the mitigating factor contained in DATE of the [ NORP ] GPE . PERSON ’s confessions are also corroborated by the statement of ORG and even extended despite threats to his person and family . This reinforces the credibility of PERSON ’s confessions . The court does not give credence to the suggestion that A. had no choice , in view of the procedural attitude adopted by PERSON , but to make a confession of his own , the less so since in so doing he has broadened PERSON ’s statements .

At the court ’s hearing of DATE , PERSON stated that he had not felt at liberty to make [ his own ] statements before the NORP court and that the statements which he had made before the GPE investigators had been put into his mouth after they had driven him crazy by raising the case of PERSON , whom he had known well . The court does not , however , consider it likely that PERSON did not make his confessions in complete freedom and in so doing takes into account what the NORP court found in its criminal judgment concerning the way in which PERSON had made his statements at the hearing in GPE and the fact that this statement confirmed what PERSON had earlier stated before the GPE investigators . In contrast , this court ’s own observation at the hearing has given it the impression that PERSON did not feel at liberty to make a true statement or in any case to confirm what he had earlier stated before the GPE investigators and the NORP criminal judge without further incriminating himself in view of the prosecution for which the GPE public prosecutor has requested his extradition . The court sees no circumstances on the basis of which it should be doubted that the statements initially taken from PERSON by the GPE investigators had lawfully come about ; nor has the defence asked for the GPE investigators concerned who questioned PERSON to be called as witnesses . Finally , the statements of both PERSON are supported in various stake - outs and the recordings of private communication ( opnemen van vertrouwelijke communicatie , ‘ OVC’s’ ) .

Considering the connection with ORG ’s confession before the NORP court and the other items of evidence the court concludes that PERSON ’s statement about the involvement of [ the applicant ] in the facts charged ... is sufficiently corroborated by other evidence and can therefore be admitted as evidence by the court . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal in on points of law ( cassatie ) with ORG . He submitted CARDINAL ground of appeal ( cassatiemiddel ) raising CARDINAL complaints : firstly , that ORG had failed to present proper reasoning as to why it relied on CARDINAL particular statement by PERSON ; and secondly , that it had mistakenly concluded that the statements given by PERSON were sufficiently supported by other evidence to prove the applicant ’s intent to commit and participate in the commission of the crime .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Procurator General ( PERSON ) to ORG expressed as his advisory opinion that the second leg of the applicant ’s ground of appeal should be upheld . He considered that the evidence that had led to the applicant ’s conviction had been based solely or to a decisive extent on the statements made by PERSON at the pre - trial stage , thus leading to a violation of LAW ( d ) of the LAW . In particular , the Procurator General found that ORG had merely sought to determine whether PERSON ’s statements could be relied upon in the face of corroborating evidence ; it had not , however , determined whether the applicant ’s conviction was based solely or to a decisive extent on PERSON ’s statements .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on points of law and confirmed the judgment of ORG . In its reasoning ORG did not deal directly with the first leg of the applicant ’s ground for appeal . As relevant to the case before this Court , ORG considered that ORG had been entitled to rely on the statements made by PERSON since that witness had appeared at the hearing and the applicant had been able to put questions to him as well as present arguments relating to the validity of PERSON ’s statements . The fact that PERSON had invoked his right not to testify did not lead to a violation of LAW ( d ) of the LAW . Ex proprio motu , ORG held that the cassation proceedings had lasted too long , for which it compensated the applicant by reducing his prison sentence by DATE . The judgment was published in GPE Law Reports ( PERSON , “ GPE ” ) DATE , no . CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Articles of the Code of Criminal Procedure relevant to the case are the following :

“ A witness shall be excused the duty to answer a question put to him if in so doing he would expose himself or CARDINAL of his relatives in the ascending or the descending line ex transverso [ i.e. siblings , uncles , aunts , nieces and nephews , etc . ] , whether connected by blood or by marriage , in the second or third degree of kinship , or his spouse or former spouse , or registered partner or former registered partner , to the risk of criminal prosecution . ”
“ CARDINAL . The following only shall be recognised as legal evidence :
CARDINAL . the court ’s own observation ;
CARDINAL . NORP statements made by the defendant ;
CARDINAL . NORP statements made by witnesses ;
CARDINAL . statements made by experts ;
CARDINAL . written documents .
CARDINAL . No proof is required of generally known facts or circumstances . ”
“ CARDINAL . ...
CARDINAL . NORP The court shall not hold it proven on the evidence of CARDINAL witness that the suspect has committed the act with which he is charged . ”
“ The expression ‘ written ORG means :

CARDINAL . documents drawn up by public bodies or civil servants concerning matters coming within the competence entrusted to them , including documents drawn up by a person in the public service of a foreign state or an international intergovernmental organisation ;
CARDINAL . all other documents ; but these shall only be valid in connection with the content of other items of evidence . ... ”

CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE , GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL , ORG held that the use in evidence of an official report containing an incriminating statement not made at the trial hearing was not ipso facto impermissible , and in particular not incompatible with LAW and CARDINAL ( d ) . There would in any case be no incompatibility if the defence had had the opportunity to test the reliability of the statement and challenge it by questioning the person who had made it as a witness . Moreover , even if such an opportunity was lacking , the use in evidence of such a report was permissible if there was “ considerable support ” for the statement in other items of evidence ( die verklaring in belangrijke mate steun vindt in andere bewijsmiddelen ) .

CARDINAL . In its judgments of DATE , GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL , and CARDINAL DATE , GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL , ORG clarified the expression “ considerable support ” by construing it in the sense that it was already sufficient if the suspect ’s involvement in the act charged was sufficiently confirmed by other evidence .
